drown.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to die from being under water for too long, or to kill someone in this way
drown.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Many people drowned when the boat overturned.
Jane was drowned in the river.
Depressed, Peter tried to drown himself.
drown.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if a loud noise drowns out another sound, it prevents it from being heard
drown.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: A train blew its whistle and drowned his voice.
The noise of the battle was drowned out by his aircraftâ€™s engine.
drown.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to cover something, especially food, with more liquid than is necessary or nice
drown.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The fish was drowned in a rich sauce.
drown.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to have a very strong feeling or a serious problem that is difficult to deal with
drown.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Relief agencies are drowning in frustration.
The country is drowning in debt.
